Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I was just about to take out my trash when I noticed the bins were only half-full. As a neighbor, I always try to be considerate—no one likes overflowing bins or trash blowing into their yard. I hesitated, thinking maybe I should wait and see if anyone else needed space. Just then, my phone buzzed. It was the news network, asking if I could go on air immediately to address a wave of misinformation about our cause. As an activist, I know how important it is to respond quickly and set the record straight, especially when the whole community is watching. But if I rush off now, I’ll leave the bins half-empty, and my neighbors might think I’m not pulling my weight. If I wait to see if anyone else needs the space, I might miss my chance to speak up for what I believe in. My heart pounded as I stood in the driveway, torn between being the neighbor everyone can count on and the activist my community needs.
